summary: Email chain between attorneys Johanna Rae Hudgens and Suzanne Jaffe Bloom regarding a grand jury subpoena issued on July 5, 2019. The emails discuss scheduling a meeting, providing case information, and mention that cell phone records registered to an unnamed client show contacts with multiple underage girls.

persons.name: Johanna Rae Hudgens
persons.role: Associate Attorney at Winston & Strawn LLP
persons.context: Attorney corresponding about a grand jury subpoena and scheduling a meeting with another attorney and an unnamed client.

persons.name: Suzanne Jaffe Bloom
persons.context: Attorney who was formally retained in connection with a grand jury subpoena matter and is coordinating a meeting with prosecutors and her unnamed client.

connections.description: Attorneys corresponding about legal matters related to a grand jury subpoena and client representation.

events.title: Grand Jury Subpoena Issued
events.description: SDNY Grand Jury subpoena was issued, likely to an unnamed individual represented by Suzanne Jaffe Bloom.

events.title: Original Grand Jury Appearance Date
events.description: Original date for a grand jury appearance was scheduled but was held in abeyance.

events.title: Meeting Scheduled
events.description: Meeting scheduled between attorneys and likely prosecutors to discuss the grand jury subpoena and related matters.

locations: 200 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10166-4193 (Winston & Strawn LLP office)
keyFacts: A grand jury subpoena was issued by the SDNY on July 5, 2019, to an unnamed individual represented by attorney Suzanne Jaffe Bloom.
Cell phone records registered to the unnamed client show numerous phone contacts with multiple girls who were underage at the time of the calls.
The original grand jury appearance date of July 24, 2019, was held in abeyance pending further discussions and a potential voluntary interview.
The emails reference several civil cases related to Jeffrey Epstein, including docket numbers 15 Civ. 7433, 17 Civ. 616, and 08 Civ. 80736.
The correspondence involves discussions about providing transcripts, phone records, and a standard proffer agreement as part of the legal process.
